Award.AwardTitle: CRII: RI: Fair, Efficient, and Truthful Resource Allocation in Dynamic Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Through the integration of artificial intelligence (AI), economics, and computation this project investigates novel solutions for resource allocation in dynamic environments and situations that lack transferable currency. With the advent of online platforms, economic theory emerges as a fundamental approach to promote desirable social properties of efficiency, fairness, and truthfulness in a variety of domains such as shift scheduling, course registration, cloud computing, and crowdsourcing. These new applications are beyond the scope of classical economic theory and market design. Complex scenarios involving changing preferences, dynamic populations, and online items require novel, practical, and scalable solutions. This project tackles a variety of fundamental problems at the intersection AI and economics while enriching the algorithmic and societal understanding of resource allocation in dynamic settings. This contrasts with classical mechanisms that either focus solely on economic aspects of resource allocation in static and offline settings or disregarded social aspects such as fairness. New techniques investigated in this project seek to expand the algorithmic aspects of resource allocation and explore the limits of feasibility for dynamic fair allocation. Advances here can have profound impact in designing efficient mechanisms to allocate resources fairly while incentivizing truthful behavior among the participants.<br/> <br/>Specifically, the project studies two interconnected components: (1) sequential allocation under uncertainty, by synthesizing models studied in AI with economic theory to investigate, analyze, and create new mechanisms that are fair and discourage strategic manipulation in environments where agents' preferences are evolving (e.g. nurse scheduling and course allocation); and (2) online mechanisms, by employing insights from algorithm design and AI to study fairness and efficiency of allocation mechanisms when agents arrive and depart over time or the availability of items is uncertain (e.g. food bank organizations and crowdsourcing platforms). The new techniques aim to exploit the mathematical framework of decision making under uncertainty as well as axiomatic approaches of algorithmic economic and mechanism design to develop theoretical models for dynamic resource allocation, and employ the multiagent design paradigm to investigate the relation between the well-established mechanisms in fair allocation problems. Ultimately, the findings of this research will lead to the development of robust systems for practical applications in dynamic settings that demand efficient and socially desirable decisions.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to investigate the practical boundaries of achieving fair, efficient, and truthful allocations in sequential and dynamic settings, design algorithms that achieve such properties, and make these solutions accessible to the public.

Research conducted under this project has resulted in noteworthy progress in the fair and efficient distribution of resources, yielding the following key outcomes:

1. Development of practical algorithms for the fair distribution of resources that arrive over time, without prior knowledge of the resources, while ensuring efficiency benchmarks like non-wastefulness.

2. Design and characterization of sequential algorithms for allocating resources in a fair and efficient manner while promoting truthful reporting of preferences.

3. Creation of computationally efficient algorithms for the fair distribution of goods (e.g., food donations, gifts) or undesirable tasks (e.g., household chores), resilient to noise in reported preferences.

4. Development of a deeper understanding of strategic behavior and incentives in two-sided allocation decisions under preferences, and examining their impact on the fairness and stability of the resulting outcomes.

The project's findings have been disseminated through numerous publications in conferences and journals. It has also played a pivotal role in the professional training and development of one postdoctoral fellow, five graduate students, ten undergraduate students, and several REU students. As part of its outreach initiatives, the PI organized workshops for underrepresented K-12 students.

In an effort to promote the adoption of proven solutions and facilitate the learning of allocation algorithms, the PI spearheaded the creation of the not-for-profit web platform, MatchU.ai. This platform, attracting thousands of users globally, seamlessly integrates research and education. It provides a comprehensive suite of well-established resource allocation algorithms, allowing users to apply and learn about them through intuitive visual interactions.
